questions.text: A 48-year-old female patient, presented to the clinic with palpitation and a three to four-year history of low potassium level and hypertension. She was initially treated with a high potassium diet and potassium supplements. After a few months, she was admitted to the hospital with an acute hypertensive episode and hypokalemia. Her plasma renin and aldosterone levels were low. The CT scan was as shown in the above image. The patient was successfully treated with a high potassium diet, triamterene and atenolol. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The above clinical history, with features of uncontrolled hypertension, hypokalemia, low plasma renin and aldosterone levels are diagnostic of Liddle syndrome.
  • The above CT-image shows normal bilateral adrenal glands. Note that the normal adrenal glands on CT take on the appearance of an upside down "V" or "Y" often (arrows).
  • Also in the above history the patient responded to treatment with triamterene which is the drug of choice for Liddle syndrome.

Liddle syndrome:

  • Liddle's syndrome, is a rare disease with autosomal dominant inheritance.
  • It is characterized frequently by severe early-onset, salt-sensitive hypertension, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, low plasma renin activity and hypoaldosteronism.
  • It is caused by disproportionate salt and water reabsorption at the distal nephron.
  • It occurs due to the abnormalities in the collecting tubule sodium channel function, also called the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) or the amiloride-sensitive sodium channel which leads to excess reabsorption of sodium and loss of potassium from the renal tubule, and hypertension due to an increase in extracellular volume.
  • These patients respond well to epithelial Na+ channel blocker drugs (e.g., amiloride or triamterene) and a low sodium diet.

Why not Conn syndrome?

Patients with Conn syndrome or primary hyperaldosteronism also presents with similar feature such as uncontrolled hypertension, hypokalemia, low renin levels. However, the plasma aldosterone levels are high, and the CT-image usually reveals unilateral or bilateral adrenal hyperplasia/ adenoma/ carcinoma.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page number:2964,2965

questions.text: The ECG shown in the image is suggestive of?
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows Mobitz type Il block, which is characterized by sudden dropped beat, without progressive prolongation of the PR interval.

  • Mobitz Il is usually due to failure of conduction at the level of the His-Purkinje system (i.e. below the AV node).

ECG characteristics of various heart blocks:

  • First degree heart block: PR interval is prolonged but there are no dropped beats.
  • Second-degree AV block: It is sub classified as Mobitz type I (Wenckebach) or Mobitz type II.
  • Mobitz type I block is characterized by a progressively lengthening PR interval, shortening of the RR interval, followed by a pause (dropped beat/s) that is less than two times the immediately preceding RR interval on the electrocardiogram (ECG).
  • Mobitz type Il block, which is characterized by sudden dropped beat/s, without progressive prolongation of the PR interval.
  • Second degree heart block with a fixed ratio of P waves: QRS complexes are referred to as 2:1, 3:1, 4:1 etc.
  • Third degree heart block: The atrial rate is more than ventricular rate with broad QRS complexes.

The two rates are independent.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page number:1882

questions.text: A 50 year old woman presented with a 7 month history of erythema and swelling of periorbital region and papules and plaques of dorsolateral aspect of forearms, DIP and knuckles with ragged cuticles. There was no muscle weakness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts Gottron's papules and the clinical situation suggests Dermatomyositis.

Gottron's papules - Hallmark sign of Dermatomyositis

  • Violaceous flat topped papules seen on metacarpophalangeal and inter-phalangeal joints

The given findings are consistent with inflammatory myopathy.

  • Other signs of dermatomyositis include:
  • Heliotropic rash on eyelids - purple rash around eyelids wih edema
  • Periungal telangiectasia
  • Mechanic's hand
  • Shawl sign
  • Poikiloderma - ragged cuticles
  • Calcinosis cutis
  • Progressive and symmetrical proximal muscle wasting occurs but at times the muscle strength appears normal.
  • Most sensitive and specific lab indicator of muscle disease activity - elevated serumCPK or CK.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page number:2820

questions.text: 18 year old male patient presented to ED with acute onset seizures. MRI brain axial image is given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Axial MRI brain post-contrast image shows multiple small subcentimeter cystic lesions with a hyperintense eccentric dot within s/o scolex in the bilateral cerebral hemisphere and pons. These are suggestive of neurocysticercosis (Vesicular stage).

Neuroimaging findings constitute the primary major diagnostic criteria. Major neuroimaging findings include cystic lesions with or without rim enhancement, nodular calcifications, or multiloculated cystic lesions in subarachnoid space or ventricles. CT is more sensitive to identifying calcified lesions, while MRI is better to identify scolex and enhancement.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page number:1791, 1792, 1793

choices.text: Dynamic left ventricular outflow tract obstruction
Systolic anterior motion of mitral valve
Mitral regurgitation with anteriorly directed regurgitant jet

questions.text: A 19-year-old basketball player collapses during a match and regains consciousness several minutes later. He reveals that he has had similar episodes before. His older brother, a soccer player, had died suddenly at the age of 22 years during a soccer game due to a heart ailment. Which of the following is least likely to be found on echocardiography in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of exercise intolerance (syncope) in the patient and family history of sudden cardiac death in his elder brother at a young age is suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). Mitral regurgitation with posteriorly directed regurgitant jet is usually seen on echocardiogram in HCM. ECG and echocardiogram are used to confirm the diagnosis of HCM.

HCM is characterized by myofiber disarray in the heart, resulting in a hypertrophic myocardium. The hypertrophy leads to the following pathophysiological changes in HCM:

  • Diastolic dysfunction - presenting as exercise intolerance
  • Systolic anterior motion (SAM) of the mitral valve
  • The hypertrophied muscles result in a narrow outflow tract
  • This leads to the production of a high-velocity jet pulling the mitral leaflets towards the septum posteriorly
  • SAM leads to mitral regurgitation
  • Dynamic left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction

Echocardiography features of HCM are as follows:

  • Left ventricular wall thickness >15 mm
  • Hypertrophied heart more confined to the interventricular septum resulting in banana-shaped ventricular cavity

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page number :1969, 1970

questions.text: A 44-year-old female with sarcoidosis came for follow-up. Which is the stage of disease from the chest radiograph shown?
questions.solution:
The chest radiograph demonstrates bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy with normal bilateral lung fields.

The standard scoring system for chest involvement in sarcoidosis was described by Scadding in 1961.

Stage I- Hilar or paratracheal lymphadenopathy

Stage |I- Both lung and parenchymal infiltrates

Stage |I|- Lung parenchymal infiltrates

Stage IV- Fibrosis

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page number :2831

questions.text: A 48-year-old HIV-positive patient presented with low-grade fever and breathing difficulty. HRCT axial image is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
HRCT axial section shows bilateral ground-glass opacities, cysts, pneumatoceles, and thickened interlobular septa.

  • These radiographic features are suggestive of PCP. PCP is an opportunistic infection occurring in HIV patients, with 80% of the patients having CD4 counts less than 200/uL.
  • A normal HRCT excludes PCP.
  • Pneumothorax and pneumatoceles are also seen typically in PCP.

Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page number:1692, 1693, 1694

questions.text: A 42-year-old female, presents to the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. She was the driver involved in a frontal collision where her car was struck by another vehicle, causing significant damage to the front end. She was wearing his seatbelt at the time of the accident. She complains of severe pain in his right knee and hip. Identify the type of injury labelled as "B".
questions.solution:
• Motor vehicle crash associated with a point of impact of the knee joint of the driver on the dashboard of the car could induce a fracture dislocation of the acetabulum and hip joint (transmission of force from the knee joint to the hip socket – an indirect blunt mechanism)

Reference: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition, part-4, chapter-26, page number:346

questions.text: A 40-year-old male, is brought to the emergency department by ambulance following a residential fire accident. He was trapped inside his burning home for several minutes before being rescued by firefighters. On arrival, he was in severe distress and appears to be in shock. His skin is charred, and he is covered in soot. He was conscious but disoriented. Examination reveals extensive burns covering more than 50% of his total body surface area, with areas of full-thickness involvement. After initial resuscitation and management, he survived. STG was done over his chest area. And skin substitute was used for covering his upper limbs. Identify the skin substitute?
questions.solution:
• The mainstay of burn wound repair has been the split-skin autograft and, at >50% TBSA, the burn area exceeds the donor site area.
  • The dermal matrix strategy, pioneered by Jack Burke, sought to redress some of these issues. In producing a ‘scafold’ to allow autologous tissue in-growth and establish a ‘neodermis’ (‘active’ temporisation), he improved the outcome of the thin, meshed skin graft. A completely synthetic, biodegradable polymer version has also been developed
  • Mefix, Fixomull and Biobrane are used in partial thickness burns.

Reference: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition, part-6, chapter-46, page number:676

questions.text: 45-year-old woman, presents to a surgeon with a chief complaint of a painless lump in her left breast that she noticed during bathing. She reports that the lump has been present for the past two months and has gradually increased in size. She denies any associated nipple discharge, skin changes, or breast pain. A mammogram was done, suggestive of malignancy BIRADS-5. Patient was planned for excision of lump and sentinel LN biopsy. Identify the dye used for SLN biopsy?
questions.solution: Reference: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition, chapter-8, page number:937

choices.text: Around the nerve for regional anaesthesia
At the site of insertion of RFA probe

questions.text: A 58-year-old female, teacher by profession, presents to the vascular clinic complaining of progressively worsening varicose veins in her left leg. She reports aching and heaviness in the affected leg, particularly after prolonged periods of standing or sitting. She is bothered by the visible, dilated veins that have become more prominent over the past few years. In doppler study there was incompetence of SFJ. And surgeon planned radio frequency ablation. Below is the photo of ongoing procedure. Where is tumescent anaesthetic agent infiltrated?
questions.solution:
• The basic concept is that a treatment device is inserted into the incompetent axial vein percutaneously.
  • The vein is surrounded by tumescent local anaesthetic solution. This compresses the vein onto the treatment device, emptying it of blood.
  • It also hydro-dissects tissues such as nerves away from the zone of injury. Finally, it acts as a heat sink, mopping up excess thermal energy to prevent remote damage.
  • The treatment device then produces thermal energy that destroys the structure of the vein, resulting in permanent occlusion.

Reference: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition, part-10, chapter-62, page number 1033, 1034

questions.text: A 45-year-old male, presents to the O.P.D. with a painful lump in his right groin that he noticed while lifting heavy boxes at work. He describes the pain as a dull ache that worsens with coughing, straining, or lifting. He reports occasional episodes of nausea but denies vomiting or changes in bowel habits. He mentions that the lump disappears when he lies down but reappears upon standing or straining. On examination he was found to have right side indirect uncomplicated inguinal hernia. He was fit for surgery. Below is the intra operative picture of the procedure. Which procedure is being done?
questions.solution:
• Bassini, Shouldice and Desarda are all suture tissue repairs
  • Lichtenstein is mesh repair: in the 1980s Lichtenstein described a tension-free, simple, fat, polypropylene mesh repair for inguinal hernia. The initial part of the operation is identical to Bassini’s. Once the hernia sac has been removed and any medial defect closed, a piece of mesh measuring 8 × 15 cm is placed over the posterior wall, behind the spermatic cord, and is slit to wrap around the spermatic cord at the deep inguinal ring. Loose sutures hold the mesh to the inguinal ligament and conjoint tendon.
  • In 1890, Edoardo Bassini described a suture repair for inguinal hernia that remained the basis of open repair for over 100 years (Figure 64.14). The surgeon enters the inguinal canal by opening its anterior wall, the external oblique aponeurosis. The spermatic cord is dissected free and the presence of a lateral or a medial hernia is confrmed. The sac of a lateral hernia is separated from the cord, opened and any contents reduced. The sac is then sutured closed at its neck and excess sac removed. If there is a medial hernia then the sac is inverted and the transversalis fascia is suture plicated. Sutures are now placed between the conjoint tendon above and the inguinal ligament below, extending from the pubic tubercle to the deep inguinal ring. The posterior wall of the inguinal canal is thus strengthened.
  • Shouldice modification: In this operation, the transversalis fascia is opened by a central incision from the deep inguinal ring to the pubic tubercle and then closed to create a two-layered posterior wall (double breasting). The external oblique is closed in a similar fashion.
  • Desarda has described an operation where a 1- to 2-cm strip of external oblique aponeurosis lying over the inguinal canal is isolated from the main muscle, but left attached both medially and laterally. It is then sutured to the conjoint tendon and inguinal ligament, reinforcing the posterior wall of the inguinal canal. As the abdominal muscles contract, this strip of aponeurosis tightens to add further physiological support to the posterior wall.

Reference: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition, part-11, chapter-64, page number 1069

questions.text: A surgeon should be knowing the different positions of the appendix while going for appendectomy. Which is the most common position and which is the least common position?

questions.text: A 32-year-old female, is brought to the emergency department by ambulance following a motor vehicle collision. On arrival, she is conscious but in severe pain. She complains of intense pain in her left flank and abdomen. She appears pale, diaphoretic, and tachycardic. Gross hematuria is noted. Computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis with intravenous contrast was done. Identify the grade of renal trauma?

choices.text: Piper forceps - aftercoming head of breach

questions.text: Name and use of the following image?
questions.solution:
Image is showing piper forceps, which is specialized for use in after coming head of breech.

It has long backward curving shanks and reverse pelvic curve.

Wrigly’s forcep: it used in cephalic presenting fetus.

It has short stems and blades are small. It is most commonly used outlet forcep.

KIELLAND FORCEP: it is used for cephalic presentation.

It is used for rotational assisted vaginal delivery

Has less pelvic curve allowing correction of an asynclitic cephalic presentation.

Used for malpositioned fetal head at full dilated cervix.

It has sliding lock.

Reference: William’s Obstetrics 26th edition, chapter 28, page number. 547

questions.text: A 40 year old female came to gynec OPD with complain of intermenstrual bleeding. There is no any other complain. On doing hysteroscopy following findings seen. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shows small mass arising from endometrial cavity and inside uterine cavity. It is suggestive of endometrial polyp.

Reference: berek & novak’s gynecology, 16th Edition, Chapter 26, Page number. 630

questions.text: A primigravida patient came to labour room. On examination, Her fetal heart is 120/min.A resident doctor is adviced to do the following test shown in image which is known as?
questions.solution:
Image is showing cardiotocography.

It shows change in fetal HR along with uterine contraction.

There is 2 transducer probe.

  • Upper probe measures uterine contraction
  • lower probe measures heart rate of fetus

Reference: Aria’s High risk pregnancy, 5th Edition, Chapter number. 7, Page number.111

questions.text: A 45 year old female came to OPD with complain of heavy menstrual bleeding since 1 month. On ultrasonography, her uterus is normal, ET-9 MM.Her endometrial smapling done by following instrument which is known as?
questions.solution:
Image is showing pipelle curette. It is used for sampling endometrium.

It is attached to electric vaccume pump.

Reference: berek & novak’s gynecology, 16th Edition, Chapter 26, Page number. 630

questions.text: This anatomic landmark indicates?
questions.solution:
ARCUS TENDINOUS FASCIA PELVIS: it is tendinous insertion of pelvic floor muscle

It attaches from pubic bone to ischial spine

It is level 2 de lancey support of uterus

Endopelvic tissue attaches with it.

Reference: berek & novak’s gynecology, 16th Edition, Chapter 26, Page number. 630

questions.solution:
4 KEY FEATURE OF PAS ON USG:

  1. Excessive lacunae
  2. Loss of retroplacental hypoechoic space
  3. Abnormalities of uterine bladder serosa interface
  4. Colour Doppler abnormalities

Reference: Aria’s High risk pregnancy, 5th Edition, Chapter number. 10, Page number.143

questions.text: Identify the causative organism for the below given condition?
questions.solution:
Hand -Foot-Mouth Disease

  • Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a clinical syndrome characterized by an oral enanthem and a macular, maculopapular, or vesicular rash of the hands and feet .
  • HFMD was first described in a summer outbreak that occurred in Toronto, Canada in 1957 and was caused by coxsackie virus A16. Since then, at least 15 other enterovirus serotypes have been shown to cause HFMD, most commonly Coxsackie virus A serotypes.
  • D/D- Herpangina is a benign clinical syndrome characterized by fever and a painful papulo-vesiculo-ulcerative oral enanthem, caused by 22 enterovirus serotypes, most commonly Coxsackie virus A serotypes.
  • Coxsackie virus A16 and enterovirus A71 serotypes are most frequently associated with HFMD and are responsible for the majority of large outbreaks.
  • Other viruses include Coxsackie virus A 5,6,7,9,10 and Coxsackie virus B 2,5 and some Echoviruses.
  • HFMD and herpangina usually occur during the summer and early autumn.
  • The viruses that cause HFMD usually are transmitted from person to person by the fecal-oral route, by contact with oral and respiratory secretions and vesicle fluid.
  • INCUBATION PERIOD- typically is three to five days.
  • CLINICAL FEATURES- presents with complaints of mouth or throat pain (in verbal children) or refusal to eat (in nonverbal children). Prodromal symptoms usually are absent but can include fever, fussiness, abdominal pain, emesis, and diarrhea.
  • Examination findings — The cardinal findings of HFMD are the oral enanthem and the exanthem. Oral enanthem — The oral lesions of HFMD are anterior to the faucial pillars, most commonly on the tongue and buccal mucosa less commonly in the gingivolabial groove and on the soft and hard palates; and occasionally on the uvula, lips, and tonsils.
  • Exanthem —may be macular, maculopapular, or vesicular. The skin lesions of HFMD are non The lesions typically resolve in three to four days. The exanthem typically involves the hands (dorsum of the fingers, interdigital area, palms), feet (dorsum of the toes, lateral border of the feet, soles, heels), buttocks, legs (upper thighs), and arms.
  • COMPLICATIONS-HFMD caused by enterovirus A71 has been associated with severe illness, complicated by central nervous system disease (rhombencephalitis, acute flaccid paralysis, aseptic meningitis), pulmonary edema and hemorrhage, and heart failure.
  • DIAGNOSIS- made clinically, based upon the typical appearance and location of the oral enanthem and exanthema.
  • CLINICAL COURSE- HFMD generally is a mild clinical syndrome. Complete resolution of symptoms and signs typically occurs within 7 to 10 days. However, complications may occur,
  • MANAGEMENT- Mainly supportive. Children with complications may require hospitalization. No specific antiviral therapy is available for the treatment of the enteroviruses. Pain and discomfort due to fever can be managed with ibuprofen or acetaminophen. Children who are unable to drink sufficiently to maintain hydration should be hospitalized for parenteral fluid therapy.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, Volume 1, 21st Edition (International Edition) page number:1692

questions.text: Vitamin A deficiency is a common public health problem. What stage of WHO classification of Xerophthalmia does the below image depict?
questions.solution:
• Vitamin A is a fat-soluble micronutrient that cannot be synthesized de novo by mammals; thus it is an obligatory dietary factor.
  • As a fat-soluble micronutrient, vitamin A is recognized as being essential for all vertebrates for normal vision, reproduction, cell and tissue differentiation, and functions of the immune system.
  • Vitamin A Deficiency :If the growing child has a well-balanced diet and obtains vitamin A from foods rich in vitamin A or provitamin A, the risk of vitamin A deficiency is small. However, even subclinical vitamin A deficiency can have serious consequences.
  • Clinical Manifestations – Symptoms of vitamin A deficiency are associated with changes in epithelial cell morphology and functions.
  • Characteristic epithelial changes result from vitamin A deficiency, including proliferation of basal cells, hyperkeratosis, and formation of stratified cornified squamous epithelium.
  • The most characteristic and specific signs of vitamin A deficiency are eye lesions, but these may manifest rather late in the progression of vitamin A deficiency, develop insidiously, and rarely occur before age 2 yr.
  • An earlier symptom of vitamin A deficiency is delayed dark adaptation, as a result of reduced resynthesis of rhodopsin; this may progress to night blindness.
  • Photophobia is a common symptom. As vitamin A deficiency progresses, the corneal and conjunctival epithelial tissues of the eye become severely altered because of a lack of sufficient RA for normal epithelial cell differentiation.
  • Stages in vitamin A deficiency include corneal keratinization and opacity, susceptibility to infection, and formation of dry, scaly layers of cells (xerophthalmia)
  • The conjunctival membrane undergoes keratinization and may develop foamy-appearing plaques (Bitôt spots). When lymphocytes infiltrate the cornea in later stages of infection, it degenerates irreversibly (keratomalacia and corneal ulceration), resulting in irreversible blindness.
  • These eye lesions are primarily diseases of the young and are a major cause of blindness in developing countries.
  • WHO Classification for grades of Xerophthalmia due Vitamin A deficiency.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 1, 21st Edition (International Edition) page number:363

choices.text: Caused due to infection from virus belonging to Togaviridae family
Leukopenia with a relative lymphocytosis in seen in blood
Effective antiviral therapy is available for treatment
Fetal malformations are associated with intrauterine infection of the virus

questions.text: Which of the following is true for the following disease?
questions.solution:
• Image shows child with Parotitis most commonly seen in Mumps.
  • Mumps is an acute self-limited infection.
  • It is characterized by fever, bilateral or unilateral parotid swelling and tenderness, and the frequent occurrence of meningoencephalitis and orchitis.
  • Mumps virus is in the family Paramyxoviridae. It is a single-stranded pleomorphic RNA virus. Mumps virus exists as a single serotype and humans are the only natural host.
  • Spreads from person to person by respiratory droplets. Virus appears in the saliva from up to 7 days before to as long as 7 days after onset of parotid The period of maximum infectiousness is 1-2 days before to 5 days after onset of parotid swelling.
  • The Health Infection Control Practices Advisory Committee recommends an isolation period of 5 days after onset of parotitis for patients with mumps in both community and healthcare settings.
  • Virus targets the salivary glands, central nervous system (CNS), pancreas, testis, and, to a lesser extent, thyroid, ovaries, heart, kidneys, liver, and joint synovia.
  • Incubation period ranges from 12 to 25 days but is usually 16-18 days.
  • Clinical presentation asymptomatic or nonspecific symptoms to the typical illness associated with parotitis with or without complications involving several body systems. The typical patient presents with a prodrome lasting 1-2 days consisting of fever, headache, vomiting, and achiness. Parotitis follows and may be unilateral or bilateral.
  • Diagnosis -made on the basis of a history of exposure to mumps infection, an appropriate incubation period, and development of typical clinical findings. Confirmation of the presence of parotitis could be made with demonstration of an elevated serum amylase value. Leukopenia with a relative lymphocytosis is a common finding. A significant increase in serum mumps immunoglobulin G antibody between acute and convalescent serum specimens as detected by complement fixation, neutralization hemagglutination, or enzyme immunoassay tests establishes the diagnosis.
  • Complications of mumps are meningitis, with or without encephalitis, and gonadal (orchitis, oophoritis) involvement. Uncommon complications include conjunctivitis, optic neuritis, pneumonia, nephritis,pancreatitis, mastitis, and thrombocytopenia. Complications can occur in the absence of parotitis especially in immunized individuals.
  • Maternal infection with mumps during the first trimester of pregnancy results in increased fetal wastage. No fetal malformations have been associated with intrauterine mumps infection.
  • No specific antiviral therapy is available for mumps. Management should be aimed at reducing the pain associated with meningitis or orchitis and maintaining adequate hydration. Antipyretics may be given for fever.

Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics Volume 1, 21st Edition (International Edition) page number:1680
